page.title: 11Geography of Southam Area
page.content: There are two major settlement areas; the market town of Southam and the village of Stockton. Two rivers, the Stowe and the Itchen drain the land towards Leamington Spa, eventually flowing into the River Avon. Most of the land is used for arable farming. The main crops are wheat and barley. Potatoes, onions, carrots and oil seed rape are also grown. Some fields bordering rivers or streams are used as pasture. Tractors are used to pull the farm machinery including muck spreaders, ploughs, harrows and seed drills. Combine harvesters are used to collect the cereal crops. A typical farm on the edge of Southam had 226 acres: ley grass 114 acres, wheat 59 acres, barley 43 acres and potatoes 10 acres.
